text:
You know, I'd like
to think I've spent

34 years honing
and training my gut

and trying to
understand who I am.

And I do my best to check
in with it every so often.

I grew up in a small
town in West Virginia.

I went to the Naval
Academy after high school

and spent a decade in the
SEAL teams as an officer.

Generally, I wanted to explore
entrepreneurship, which
was why I pursued an MS/MBA.

Spent time recruiting
and consulting.

Also spent time speaking to
a lot of different venture

capital firms, a lot
of different startups.

Whenever I have had a few
different opportunities

for full-time employment,
really sinking in

and trying to understand,
is this what I want to do?

So saying no, there was a lot
of different steps to that.
I was very transparent.
I was very direct.

I explained there's
other career spaces
that I wanted to evaluate.

And so we ultimately
parted ways.

[LAUGHS] At first, especially
with a young family,
it's definitely nerve wracking.

But then after you start
exploring other spaces and you

realize the opportunities
that are out there, it's--
I'm glad I did it for me.

For me, it was the
right decision.

You can go do literally
anything out of here, from run

for office to start
your own company,

to move to a foreign
country, run a nonprofit.

Continue to lean into everything
that just excites you.

Ignore what everybody else is
saying at that point in time.

If you truly love
something, I firmly

believe that you'll
do just fine.
